experts_consulted.name: Fred Brooks
key_contributions: Conceptual integrity principle: one database, multiple views
Sprint structure: each sprint delivers independent user value
Four-sprint v0.1 plan with clear user flows
Decision framework: benchmark libraries empirically (Plotly vs Scatter-GL)
notable_positions: Established the 'one thing' principle: Cells is a database of measured rules with different views
Insisted on Home page for conceptual integrity (communicate intent)
Championed user flow thinking over component thinking

experts_consulted.name: Rich Hickey
key_contributions: Data as unifying concept: survey produces data, Atlas/Detail consume data
Schema design: two stores (rules, collections), document-oriented
Denormalized approach: store complete measurements, no joins
Extension path: add topology field later, additive not breaking
notable_positions: Advocated for flexible schema anticipating topology support
Proposed storing measurements as nested arrays (later rejected for query efficiency)
Settled on simple schema with documented extension path

experts_consulted.name: Barbara Liskov
key_contributions: Identified lack of data layer as root of incoherence
Clean separation: Rules (entities) vs Measurements (observations)
Query API layer: UI → Query API → IndexedDB
Composite indexes for efficient range queries
notable_positions: Advocated for normalized schema (separate Measurements store)
Emphasized clean abstractions and interface boundaries
Interest score should be computed on-demand, not stored

experts_consulted.name: Dieter Rams
key_contributions: Radical minimalism: 3 pages (Atlas, Detail, Lab), no Home
v0.1 scope control: four features, nothing more
Question-driven: 'What is minimum useful system?'
Deferred features: Collections, Compare, 3D, hierarchy to v0.2
notable_positions: Initially excluded Home page (overruled for accessibility)
Championed 'ship and learn' over planning beyond v0.1
Simplicity principle: start 2D, add 3D only if users ask

experts_consulted.name: Edward Tufte
key_contributions: 2D visualization advocacy: small multiples, no 3D distortion
Color as third dimension: diverging colormap for gamma
Data transparency: show all points, no aggregation
Coverage communication: display '22,590 / 262,144 (8.6%)' prominently
notable_positions: Strong opposition to 3D visualization (perspective distortion obscures data)
Visual detection faster than algorithmic detection for hierarchy
Sparse sampling can reveal structure if labeled honestly

experts_consulted.name: Bret Victor
key_contributions: Integrated functionality: survey and exploration should be unified
Discovery during surveying: watch rules being tested, pause to investigate
Embodied exploration: interactive 3D has value (disagreed with Tufte)
Store animation previews for instant playback on hover
notable_positions: Challenged separation of Lab (surveying) and Atlas (exploring results)
Advocated for 3D interactive visualization (overruled for v0.1)
Emphasized delight: tiny animation previews, smooth transitions

experts_consulted.name: Stephen Wolfram
key_contributions: Insight definition: discover what makes rules interesting and where they cluster
Empirical approach: benchmark libraries, don't argue aesthetics
Survey strategy: two-pass (aggregate stats, then deep analysis on promising rules)
Stratified sampling: 8.6% is valid for detecting clusters
notable_positions: Survey should be prioritized (complete dataset before complex viz)
Interest score = distance from boring regions (edge of chaos)
Algorithmic hierarchy detection is necessary for research validity (compromised to manual for v0.1)

productive_disagreements: Tufte vs Victor on 2D vs 3D visualization (resolved: start 2D, defer 3D)
Rams vs Brooks on Home page inclusion (resolved: include, but lightweight)
Hickey vs Brooks on schema flexibility (resolved: simple with extension path)
Wolfram vs Tufte on hierarchy detection (resolved: manual MVP, algorithmic later)
convergence_moments: Consensus on deferring interest scoring to v0.2
All endorsed empirical library benchmarking (Plotly vs Scatter-GL)
tension_preservation: 2D vs 3D remains open for v0.2 (user feedback will decide)
Algorithmic hierarchy detection deferred but not rejected
